Use when picturing the range is important
Sliders give a greater sense of the range that a user can set their value between. This is
useful when the position within that range is important. For example, estimating if a
measurement size can be considered small or large, or if a price value is considered low
or high.
Be careful: this range orientation can sometimes lead to user selection bias, because
they may feel that the middle of the range is safer than selecting an extreme.

(] Use Sliders when there's a range of values to choose from. A When there are fewer than five values within the Slider range, consider using a
Radio Button or a Select component to ensure a clear overview of the selection
options.
Use when an approximate value is good enough
Sliders have problems with precision, especially for users with motor disabilities where
using a cursor or finger to control the handle can prove difficult. Consider enabling the
value fields as editable in such cases. The benefit of Sliders lies in the ability for users to
quickly approximate a value and manipulate a set of results.

Give feedback as the value of the Slider changes
Where possible and performant, Sliders should act as a direct input device showing
real-time updates to the results it controls. If performing live modifications at the speed
the user can move the Slider is expensive, consider providing the updates as the handle
is released.

Consider haptic feedback for stepped Sliders
On mobile devices, discrete Sliders using stepped increments can be further enhanced
by providing haptic feedback each time the Slider snaps to a new value. This can be
beneficial for low-sighted users who may have trouble seeing markers on the Slider
track.
Provide a wide range of values to choose from
Sliders work well when there is a large range of values to choose between. When using
Sliders, make sure you provide ample increments that still provide a sense of precision
control with the movement of the handle. If there are 5 or fewer options to choose from
within the range, consider using a Radio Button or Select instead.

Key Description
Tab Handles in the Slider can receive keyboard focus and be moved by arrow keys.
Arrow Keys When moved by the arrow keys on a keyboard, handles obey the step value for the range they are in. When moving in
a range that has no step value set, handles move by 10% of the range they are in.
Up / Down Arrow The Page Up and Page Down keys can be used to make larger steps through the Slider range. By default, the page
keys multiply the default step by 5.
